Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding diversity in camas and rush lilies: can a unified approach resolve species boundaries in difficult groups?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Characterizing life's astounding diversity is fundamental to creating the stable, predictive classifications applied daily in agriculture, conservation, and medicine. Despite new genomic tools, however, species boundaries remain contentious since both the processes and traits that define species are spatially and temporally dynamic. This project uses multiple evidentiary approaches and novel protocols to test discovery-driven hypotheses of species delimitation in closely related Camassia and Hastingsia (rush lilies). Their morphological complexity, hybrids, and variable populations pose difficult classification challenges, making them ideal exemplars for defining the "best practices" of integrative taxonomy. Analysis of ecological and genetic differences, reproductive barriers, and the response of "generalist pollinators" to floral traits will add further insights into how diversity arises in a family where highly specialized pollination also occurs.

The ecological and cultural value of camas to indigenous peoples enhances the project's broad focus, which engages K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students in investigations encompassing the full scope of systematics. Volunteer partnerships will foster diverse, structured experiences in threatened habitats. Access to internet keys will further improve rare and common plant identification. Finally, ecological niche modeling and records of insect visits and flowering times may facilitate tracking the effects of climate change on plant-pollinator interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The levels of biodiversity on earth remain astonishing, despite the currently high levels of extinction. Essential to an understanding of life is the ability to distinguish meaningful groups such as families and species. Sorting and characterizing nature’s vast diversity is necessary for future use, discussion, or scientific study of organisms. However, taxonomic classification is challenging in many groups due to the complex ways that ancestral lineages and their descendants merge or separate, potentially forming new species. Our work focuses on one such difficult group, the camas lilies (Camassia) and rush lilies (Hastingsia); we aimed to better understand the speciation processes responsible for their diversity. The genera Camassia and Hastingsia also provide a tractable case study for applying integrative taxonomy, which uses multiple types of data to investigate species boundaries. We are combining genetic, morphological, ecological, and reproductive differences in analyzing these plants. Each type of data can provide information on the patterns of evolution, and they also help reveal the processes behind those patterns.

 

There are many different ways in which new species arise, go extinct, and develop traits that make them distinct and uniquely valuable. In some cases, new species may form due to changes or subdivisions in their environment leading to different ecological pressures. In other cases, new species may form due to differences in their reproductive characteristics. With flowering plants such as camas and rush lilies, such reproductive traits may have a key influence on interactions with insect pollinators (or visa versa). Genetic isolation can result from these floral differences, for example, the two Midwestern camas species are closely related and overlap in distribution, but have flowering seasons that are often separated by several weeks. 

 

We have inferred an evolutionary tree across the broader group containing these two genera, resolving deeper patterns of evolution and providing a framework in which to place detailed study of groups of these species. We have also used a type of DNA sequencing that subsamples across genomes to infer relationships at more shallow levels: between populations of species and subspecies. This exploration has demonstrated the key importance of careful analysis, ensuring that consistently supported patterns are revealed so that the incredible size of these genomic datasets does not lead to overconfidence in any particular result. Our analyses have also revealed the power of these new genome-wide datasets for exposing relationships among populations and species that were unresolved by prior investigation of morphology or separate gene regions. In camas and rush lilies, the results thus far support some existing species, but highlight other species and subspecies whose current taxonomic boundaries or proposed geographic ranges do not reflect natural lineages. For example, multiple lines of evidence now indicate that some populations in California that were originally identified as C. quamash are more closely related to C. howellii, which had been considered endemic to Oregon. In other northwestern species of Camassia, hybridization may be contributing higher levels of genetic exchange than previously recognized. Revisions have begun in both Camassia and Hastingsia; these may involve partial re-classification of certain species to incorporate new data of diverse types.

 

As more and more species are struggling due to the overwhelming impacts of humans, studies such as these allow us to better understand what species exist now and also what processes are important in the formation of new species. There are conservation concerns with some members of both of these genera and this work also highlights some of the interactions between these species and other members of their ecosystems, such as pollinators. As with all natural systems, effects placed on one species usually impact many more. The application of integrative taxonomy is the ideal for all species, allowing a broader view of patterns of diversity and a resulting classification that accurately represents actual relationships. Given limited funds, however, it is not always feasible to conduct studies that are this extensive. Using groups such as these two genera as a case study allows us to test these methods, gaining insights that may also be useful in finding the best tools for understanding the diversity present in lesser-studied groups.

 

Plant and pollinating insect specimens have been collected and will be vouchered into the University of Kansas Natural History Museum. The DNA data that has been sequenced will continue to be made available to other researchers using public databases such as GenBank. This work has also enabled scientific training at the University of Kansas of at least ten undergraduate students, two graduate students, and one postdoc in field, molecular, and/or greenhouse methods.
